title: 115_hr3179
content: The Act is titled the "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act". It includes a requirement for cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates that Federal banking agencies must provide a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for any prudential regulation that is more stringent than international standards. This includes assessing impacts on credit availability, pricing, and market liquidity. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to analyze the impact of more stringent prudential regulations on credit availability, pricing, market liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. Additionally, agencies must seek public input before implementing regulations that supersede existing ones. Federal banking agencies must seek public input before implementing prudential regulations that may supersede existing ones, ensuring transparency and accountability. This includes proposing to repeal or amend the superseded regulation or providing a rationale for not doing so, with a comprehensive analysis of costs and benefits. Federal banking agencies must issue a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act for any final rule issued before that date that established a prudential regulation more stringent than an international standard. The report should include a comprehensive analysis of costs and benefits. The appropriate Federal banking agencies must report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on any final rule that established a prudential regulation stricter than an international standard or superseded another regulation. The report should include a detailed analysis of costs and benefits. Definitions for this section include the meaning of "appropriate Federal banking agency," "banking organization," "corresponding international prudential standard," and "prudential regulation." The term "corresponding international prudential standard" refers to an international standard that a prudential regulation is based on, derived from, or similar to. Prudential regulation includes rules on capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. Prudential regulation sets requirements for banking organizations' capital, debt, and liquid assets, based on international standards. The term "international standard" refers to prudential regulations based on international prudential standards set by institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board. These standards cover capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The Financial Stability Board sets standards for capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations, including minimum requirements on capital, debt, and liquid assets. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to regulations that address similar risks as international standards.
